entry.summary: 认为移动网络应用程序正在缩小与本机应用程序差距的想法是可笑的。他们之间的鸿沟正在扩大，而不是缩小。
entry.content:
新年刚过，某种地下电缆故障导致我们家以及附近不规则区域停电 26 小时。我们不会经常断电，即使断电，停电时间通常很短，但 26 小时感觉相当漫长——尤其是在室外温度低于冰点且白天接近日历最低点的情况下。这次特别的停电令人沮丧的是，我们的电力公司 PECO 1似乎不知道到底出了什么问题，也不知道需要多长时间才能修复。

1 月 2 日上午 10 点 30 分左右停电，不久后 PECO 预计将在下午 2 点恢复供电。然后是下午 4 点，然后又短暂地下午 2 点（尽管当时实际时间是下午 2 点之后——当时我有一种沮丧的感觉，我应该拿出手电筒），然后他们声称没有已知的停电情况。我们的地区，直到最终他们停止提供我们电力何时恢复的任何估计。如果 PECO 只是用耸肩表情符号替换估计的电力恢复时间，我会给予 PECO 一些诚实的赞扬。

我一直在关注这些更新，并通过我的 iPhone 在PECO 网站上查看停电地图。我对哪个网站一点也不熟悉，因为我们的电源确实不经常停，而且我的妻子负责账单。 PECO 是我不幸使用过的最糟糕的网站之一。它的缺点包括：

  • 加载速度非常慢。 （这种缓慢不能用压倒性的需求来解释——停电并不普遍。）
  • 页面通常加载不完整。顶部只有一些页眉镀铬，下面只有白色。事实上，我今天刚刚尝试过，并得到了这个。
  • 导航很混乱，即使我弄清楚了，也需要多次点击和页面加载才能到达我想返回的页面。而且这些页面加载速度都很慢。
  • 最糟糕的是，您可能想要执行的大多数任务（包括仅检查中断状态）似乎都要求您以客户身份登录，但网站会在几分钟后自动将您注销。所以每次我回来时，我都必须重新登录。你会惊讶地发现，尽管我的凭据是自动填充的，但速度很慢，有时第一次尝试就无法接受。

基本上，PECO 的移动网站感觉就像是使用 Microsoft Excel 开发并导出的。您可能会说：“这没有任何意义，因为您从未能够使用 Excel 构建或导出网站。 ” 我会回答：“是的，完全正确。 ”

因此，每次我想查看是否有关于恢复供电的更新估计时，至少需要一两分钟等待页面加载、重新登录（这总是很慢），并探索他们难以理解的内容。站点导航。该网站确实偶尔会提示我安装他们的移动应用程序，但我的反应是“操，这可能只是他们的网站的包装。”

那是一个又冷又黑的夜晚，但第二天中午刚过，我们的电源就恢复了， 2并且一直保持恢复状态，所以我比喻性地掸了掸双手，心里想：“我希望我再也不需要使用那个该死的网站了。” ”。

昨晚，我们家又停电了。庆幸的是，这一次只持续了大约 80 分钟。当停电发生时，在尝试 PECO 这个被诅咒的网站之前，我就去了 App Store 并安装了他们的 iPhone 应用程序。这是一个启示。 PECO 的 iOS 应用程序拥有其网站所不具备的一切：快速、组织良好，而且幸运的是，可以让您保持登录状态。3

我什至会形容 PECO 的网站（至少是通过电话体验的）完全无能。我将他们的原生 iOS 应用程序描述为——我不敢相信我会用这个词——好。很难相信该网站和应用程序来自同一家公司。

这对我来说毫无意义。我希望大多数人会通过网络甚至手机使用公用事业公司。谁会想到在手机上安装电力公司的应用程序？但这是白天和黑夜的区别。我觉得自己像个傻瓜，因为在之前的 26 小时中断中，当这个应用程序可用时，我着迷地检查了他们可怕的、加载缓慢的（我只是无法强调它有多慢）、损坏的网站。

移动网络体验绝对没有理由不应该是快速、可靠、设计精良并让您保持登录状态。如果两者之一应该很糟糕，那么应该是应用程序很糟糕，而网站也运行良好。您不应该期望在口袋里随身携带公用事业公司提供的一揽子软件。但事实恰恰相反。我怀疑我的本能信念（即服务公司或公用事业公司应首先将其客户服务工作重点放在网络上，然后是本机应用程序）和我顽固的信念（邀请不应该用作名词）一样过时。 （邀请函就在那里。）

我不会将这一经历视为网络正在消亡的标志，但它确实似乎正在衰落，尤其是对于移动设备而言。 4认为移动网络应用程序正在缩小与本机应用程序差距的想法是可笑的。他们之间的鸿沟正在扩大，而不是缩小。

  1. 在 1994 年更改官方名称之前，他们的名字已经有一个多世纪了。他们应该保留旧名称而不是重新命名，尽管几十年来费城没有人只称呼他们为“PECO”。这里没有人把退伍军人体育场称为“The Vet”以外的任何名字，但如果正式将这座 20 世纪 70 年代初期粗野主义的伟大混凝土杰作正式重命名为它的绰号，那就太愚蠢了。 ↩︎︎

  2. 我认为这是墨菲定律的另一个证明，当我洗完澡后，电源又恢复了，淋浴本身并不冷，但肯定不热，更不用说足够热了。 ↩︎︎

  3. 在撰写本专栏时，我在 Pixel 4 上安装了 PECO 的 Android 应用程序并尝试了一下。它与 iOS 应用程序共享视觉设计 - 我强烈怀疑它们是由共享代码库和各种跨平台框架之一制成的。但 iPhone 应用程序速度很快（或者至少足够快），而 Android 应用程序却很慢。但我不能说其中有多少来自应用程序，有多少是因为我的 Pixel 4 已经用了五年了。但我也在我的 iPhone 12（四年前）上尝试了 iOS 应用程序，感觉也很流畅。 ↩︎︎

  4. 有点奇怪的是，现在有无数据称技术精湛的人，当他们使用“桌面应用程序”一词时，指的是网站。我个人主要认为这种用法是原生 Mac 应用程序衰落的标志。但这也是手机网站建设衰落的一个迹象。我认为也许我们看到的并不是网络整体正在消亡，而是移动网络正在消亡。 ↩︎︎

entry.title: 罗里·赛克斯 (Rory Sykes) 在洛杉矶野火中丧生，安息吧
entry.content:
Josh DuBose，KTLA 报道：

前儿童演员罗里·赛克斯 (Rory Sykes) 在帕利塞兹火灾中在马里布的家中丧生，雪莱·赛克斯 (Shelley Sykes) 的母亲在一次情感采访中分享了她的悲惨故事，并对失去儿子的悲痛表示悲痛。雪莱强忍着泪水，回忆起与 32 岁的罗里在一起的最后时刻。罗里出生时失明，患有脑瘫。

1 月 7 日，帕利塞兹火灾爆发，母子俩留在马里布的家中，相信自己很安全。然而，一夜之间，随着风力驱动的火势升级，余烬飞溅到他们的财产上，一场巨大的火灾将罗里困在他的小屋里，他走路都困难。

“我开车到他小屋的顶部，打开软管，但没有水流出，”雪莱解释道。 “我跑回去拨打 911，但 911 无法接通，所有线路都因紧急情况而停机。”

她说，尽管她尽了最大努力，罗里还是把自己锁在小屋里，并告诉他的母亲要救自己。

雪莱说，她抓起孔雀，开车去寻求帮助，但当消防队员返回时，小屋和主屋都被大火完全烧毁。官员们尚未从小屋烧焦的废墟中打捞出这位前童星的遗体。

赛克斯是迄今为止已知的 24 名死亡者之一，但至少还有 16 人仍然失踪。他的母亲在 X 上宣布了他的去世，并强调他是一名狂热的游戏玩家和苹果爱好者。事实证明，他显然也是《勇敢的火球》的狂热读者。 Rory 自己的 X feed充满了 DF 帖子的链接，直到他去世的前一天。

我和我的读者们之间的关系非同寻常。你们都认识我，我的写作和播客揭示了我是谁。我认识的人相对较少。但当一位朋友向我介绍了赛克斯的悲伤故事——以及我的上帝，他可怜的母亲，她无法拯救他——以及他的 X feed 时，我受到了打击。

我不能说我认识罗里。他似乎从来没有给我发过电子邮件，我们似乎也没有在 Twitter/X 上互动过。但我很高兴我的写作是他生活的一部分——我也很高兴它也是你生活的一部分。除了整个野火灾难令人心碎和可怕之外，我不知道还能说些什么，并提醒我们生活中的一切是多么短暂和微妙。

整个过程非常不寻常。 Meta 通常会通过邀请员工、公民领袖和其他人参与进来来改变管理其应用程序（包括 Facebook、Instagram、WhatsApp 和 Threads）的政策。任何改变通常需要几个月的时间。但扎克伯格将这一最新努力变成了一场为期六周的紧密冲刺，甚至让他的政策和诚信团队的员工措手不及。

与来自公司内部和外部的大量利益相关者进行长达数月的流程是您做出政策变更的方式，目的是尽可能不引起争议。与一个紧密的团队一起进行为期六周的冲刺是您明知会引起争议的政策改变的方式。这个过程不寻常，因为变化的性质不寻常。

在采访中，扎克伯格的十多名现任和前任 Meta 员工、高管和顾问称，他的转变有双重目的。随着特朗普先生于 1 月 20 日就职，华盛顿保守派势力方兴未艾，它将 Meta 定位为当前的政治格局。更重要的是，这些变化反映了扎克伯格先生对他的价值 1.5 万亿美元的公司应该如何运营的个人看法。他不想再对这些观点保密。

这听起来很真实，也是我对扎克伯格的看法。但它们与《泰晤士报》的报道标题背道而驰，该标题将与特朗普结盟视为主要动机。我认为很明显，与特朗普结盟只是扎克伯格将 Meta 的内容审核政策放回到他认为应该一直在的地方的幌子。扎克不是右翼，但他也不反右翼。但对于今天的大部分左派来说，任何不反右翼的人都是右翼。扎克已经不再试图安抚那些持有这种心态的人了。

在 Meta，扎克伯格开始准备改变言论政策。他知道任何举动都会引起争议，因此组建了一个由不超过十几名亲密顾问和副手组成的团队，其中包括与共和党关系密切的长期政策执行官乔尔·卡普兰(Joel Kaplan)；凯文·马丁，美国政策负责人；以及通讯主管大卫·金斯伯格（David Ginsberg）。知情人士称，扎克伯格坚持不泄密。

并给予他们信任——在扎克伯格将这些变化放到他的 Instagram 视频中之前，不要对这些变化窃窃私语。 Meta 以自己的方式、以自己的方式宣布了这些变化。

两位知情人士表示，一些员工对高管们在“仇恨行为”政策宣布之前隐瞒其变化的做法感到愤怒。虽然政策部门的人员通常会查看并评论重大修订，但这次大多数人没有机会。

一些员工在为一家由一位吃脸创始人经营的公司工作多年后，惊讶地发现自己的脸被吃掉了，这位创始人拥有公司股票的控股权，因此除了他自己之外不向任何人负责。

entry.summary: 对于哪家公司举办的主题演讲吸引了最热情的现场观众这一问题，答案总是苹果。他们就这样离开了。
entry.content:
Nvidia 首席执行官黄仁勋在 CES 2025 的主题演讲中发布了几项有趣的公告，包括新一代 RTX 50 游戏 GPU和即将推出的售价 3,000 美元的 Mac-Mini 大小的“个人 AI 超级计算机”，名为 Project Digits 。但令我最感兴趣的是主题演讲本身的规模：拉斯维加斯曼德勒湾的一个竞技场有超过 6,000 名与会者。看看它：它更像是一场摇滚音乐会，而不是一场科技主题演讲。 1

我们——你们确实非常（并且不言而喻）包括在内——在库比蒂诺的权威机构中，经常夸大苹果在新冠疫情之后的预先拍摄的主题演讲与该公司在新冠疫情之前的现场观众主题演讲的优缺点。支持新的预先拍摄格式的论点是，无论现场观众有多少（苹果公司在 Moscone West 和圣何塞会议中心举行的 WWDC 主题演讲的观众人数上限约为 5,000 人），更多的人观看视频，因此格式应该针对视频而不是现场观众进行优化。 2预拍格式还可以让 Apple 更快地讨论更多主题并引入更多演示者。当然，一切看起来都更好、更精致。因为一切都是预先拍摄好的，所以演示不仅不会失败，甚至不会出现任何问题。但你也可以说，演示是新格式的缺点，而不是优点——正如我几个月前写的关于谷歌活动中一些人工智能演示失败的文章，现场演示带来了真正的戏剧性，正如我所指出的在九月份的脚注中，我特别怀念苹果现场演示的戏剧性。

但 Nvidia CES 主题演讲的场地规模和观众热情给我留下深刻印象的是现场活动的普遍性，而不仅仅是现场演示的戏剧性。现场观众有魔力。这很重要。泰勒·斯威夫特 (Taylor Swift) 创下纪录的 Eras 巡演轰动了全世界，因为这是热情歌迷之间的共同经历。如果她没有参加那次巡演，她仍然会非常受欢迎，但她因为参加了巡演而更受欢迎。观看现场体育赛事与在电视上观看有很大不同。正如体育迷在 2020 年了解到的那样，如果没有现场观众在场，在电视上观看体育比赛会感觉怪异、平淡和低风险。

苹果在科技领域拥有这一点。即使从市值和市场份额来看，苹果公司还是一家规模较小的公司，但他们的现场主题演讲却吸引了全世界的极大关注。部分原因是苹果公司一直以其其他科技公司无法比拟的方式拥有其产品的粉丝，部分原因是苹果公司在其主题演讲上比任何其他公司都更加努力（并且工作），部分原因是史蒂夫·乔布斯（Steve Jobs）个人非常出色。具有舞台表演天赋和魅力。直到苹果从 2010 年开始退出 IDG 的 Macworld 博览会之前，苹果单枪匹马地让 Macworld 主题演讲在关注度上与整个 CES 相媲美。历史上最著名的主题演讲是 2007 年 1 月 9 日在旧金山 Macworld Expo 上发表的介绍初代 iPhone 的主题演讲。没有人记得比尔·盖茨第二天在拉斯维加斯发表的CES 2007 主题演讲中的任何内容。我敢打赌比尔盖茨本人不记得那个主题演讲中的任何内容。

在苹果停止举办现场 WWDC 主题演讲之前，那些 WWDC 主题演讲都是活动。没有史蒂夫·乔布斯，人们的热情丝毫没有减弱。对于哪家公司举办的主题演讲吸引了最热情的现场观众这一问题，答案总是苹果。他们就这样离开了。邀请数千名开发者在 Apple Park 的草坪上观看预先拍摄的 WWDC 主题演讲固然很好，但氛围却有所不同。现场观影活动不是现场表演。

对于哪家公司举办的主题演讲吸引了最热情的大量现场观众的问题，显然有一个新的答案：Nvidia。

  1. 我不会撒谎说我看了整个 Nvidia 主题演讲，但我看了足够多的内容来感受它。这很好——主要是因为英伟达正在扼杀它。他们正在提供跨多个类别的世界上最好的令人兴奋的新产品。这些都是游戏和人工智能爱好者真正关心的类别。 Project Digits 是一个真正的创新理念。黄仁勋是一位很有魅力的主持人。他很好。但我看得很清楚的一件事是他们排练得不够。或者更具体地说，当苹果公司进行现场主题演讲时，他们的排练次数几乎没有苹果公司那么多。史蒂夫·乔布斯在台上的魅力之一在于他给人的印象是即兴发挥，根据准备好的主题幻灯片大纲即兴发言。但那是一种幻觉。乔布斯排练、排练、排练，然后再排练。即使乔布斯只是即兴发挥，他也可能比其他任何人都要好，但他仍然投入了长时间的排练，以尽可能地做到最好。

    佩恩和泰勒的两半都拥护同样的观点，认为这是魔法唯一真正的“秘密”。 Teller 在 Chris Jones 2012 年为《Esquire》杂志撰写的一篇精彩简介中说道：“有时候，魔法只是某人在某件事上花费的时间比其他人合理预期的要多。” Penn Jillette在 2011 年 Unmasked 的视频采访中说道：“我会以最诚实的方式告诉你魔法的绝对秘密。魔法的秘密在于你不会愿意像我们一样努力工作，这就是全部秘密。”这基本上就是苹果新旧主题演讲的秘密。他们不仅仅比大多数公司更努力一点。他们比任何其他公司或首席执行官合理预期的工作要努力得多。

    黄仁勋很好，Nvidia 的主题演讲也很好，但他们没有像苹果那样努力工作或排练，我不认为黄仁勋会认为这样做合理或很好地利用了他的时间和注意力。 ↩︎

  2. 而且，正如我在 9 月份报道的那样（同样是在脚注中），我非常可靠地获悉，苹果公司近年来的主题演讲直播收视率比以往任何时候都高，而如今，乔布斯时代主题演讲的收视率相形见绌。当然，这并不是说苹果主题演讲的收视率比以往任何时候都高，因为格式从现场活动改为预先拍摄的视频。但确实有更多的人喜欢这种形式，而且这种改变也没有坏处。 ↩︎︎

;

我没有设计码头 - 那是Bas Ording，这是史蒂夫亲自招募的才华横溢的年轻UI设计师。但是，我的工作是将他的原型制作在MacRomind导演中，并将其变成工作代码，作为Finder团队的一部分。

在这一切的中间，当我在库比蒂诺（Cupertino）外出时，我被问到我是否想从事一个秘密项目“überbar”。向我展示了一些原型，基本上告诉我有六个人看到了它，如果泄漏，他们知道是我说话的是我。我认为是否有人终于要杀死拖拉，也可能是我。

汤姆·沃伦（Tom Warren），《边缘：》：

Microsoft正在提取另一个技巧，以吸引人们使用其Bing搜索引擎。如果您现在使用bing而不登录Microsoft帐户并搜索Google，那么您将获得一个看起来很糟糕的页面，就像... Google。

这是微软的明确尝试，以使Bing看起来像Google的特定搜索查询，而其他搜索只需列出通常没有此特殊界面的通常的Bing搜索结果即可。 Google的结果包括一个搜索栏，看起来很像Google Doodle，甚至像Google一样，在搜索栏下的一些小文本。 Microsoft甚至会自动向下滚动页面，以掩盖出现在搜索结果顶部的Bing搜索栏。

这里的想法是Edge是Windows上的默认浏览器，Edge仍然是将BING设置为默认搜索引擎的唯一浏览器。因此，许多技术上不太熟悉的Windows用户打开了浏览器（Edge）并键入“ Google”。这个技巧旨在让他们认为他们现在在Google上，我不得不说，这确实做得很好。搜索框上方缺少Google的主要徽标，这是由Google -Doodle式插图解释的。 Google本身很常见。自动滚动将页面向下移动到足以将Bing自己的页面头移出可查看的页面内容。但是，由于它们只是从Bing Page标头向下自动滚动，而不是完全隐藏它（例如，使用display: none ），您只需滚动返回即可看到它。但是，谁认为在键入搜索词并登陆回报后立即滚动呢？ （没有人。）他们甚至在“美国科技公司”的“信息框”中实际上在结果页面上有“ Google”和Google的实际徽标。你自己看看吧。

这是一个精致的肮脏技巧，我敢打赌它实际上非常好。 Google本身长期以来一直声称“ Google”是Bing上最受欢迎的术语。我敢打赌，以这种方式介绍该搜索的结果会大大增加了以为他们现在在Google上进行的用户数量，他们在Bing上进行了他们打算在Google上进行的搜索。然后再做一次，直到一些有用的朋友或同事向他们展示如何安装更好的浏览器或只是将Edge的默认搜索切换到Google 。

这是他们很长一段时间以来最经典的老式Microsoft Rat他妈的他妈的。他们曾经在80年代和90年代一直在整个过程中始终对这些类型的动作进行调整。具有欺骗性的能力，可以工作，但在其各个方面都具有合理的可否认性，无论多么薄。很高兴看到他们仍然把它拿到了他们。

★

entry.title: 也来自档案：““ beta”不是借口'
entry.content:
2006年，您的帖子确实非常适用于当今苹果情报的完美：

这里的情感是，开发人员不公平地以与非β软件相同的批判眼睛处理标有“ beta”的软件。确实，就实际的beta软件而言，我的意思是“尚未发布，但要关闭”。

发布与不发行的是需要严重限制的区别。电影评论家不要写粗略的评论。批评家不要回顾小说的非比赛手稿。

已发布标记为“ beta”的软件仍然发布了软件，并且与任何已发布的软件相同的批评水平都是公平的游戏。您不能仅仅因为想要它而“半释放” 1.0，但尚未完成。半发行就像半孕。 [...]

发布的软件到底是什么意思，但标记为“ beta”？有丢失的功能吗？所有软件都缺少功能。我从未遇到过从事重要软件项目的单个开发人员，该项目已经完全归零了功能列表。知道如何在为此发行版的功能和推迟以后的功能之间划清界限是运输艺术的很大一部分。

不，在这种情况下，“ beta”含义是“越野车”。

阅读到最后，我什至有一个徽章（礼貌我的朋友布莱恩·贝尔），苹果可以用来更清楚地标记苹果情报通知摘要。

entry.title: 来自DF档案：“作为Facebook主持人的生活”
entry.content:
我今天早些时候提到了凯西·牛顿（Casey Newton）在坦帕（Tampa）一位大型Facebook承包商上对内容主持人的生活大开眼界的《边缘》（ The Bodies in the Bodies in the The Verge ）的杰出作品。当我链接到它时，我写道：

如果这是适度Facebook的要求，那是对Facebook本身的基本概念的起诉。从理论上讲，让世界上的每个人都在他们想要的任何内容上发布并与志趣相投的人联系并扩大了他们的联系，这听起来像是一个崇高的主意。

实际上，这是一场灾难。

问题不是“每个人都可以发布他们想要的任何东西”，这就是互联网的本质，我真的相信它以一种很好的方式使沟通民主化。灾难性的部分是“与志趣相投的人相连并扩大”。这就是Facebook（在某种程度上，YouTube和Twitter）与普通旧网络论坛之类的东西之间的区别。 Facebook对他们实际做的大部分工作充满了痛苦，但是他们的自我描述的一部分是他们确实确实联系了人们。问题是某些人不应该连接，并且不应放大某些消息。

平台从根本上出了错，尽管完全按照设计的方式运行，但要求成千上万的员工粉碎自己的灵魂。

支撑。

★

entry.title: 杜德，您会得到Dell Pro Max Premium Plus
entry.content:

科技行业不懈地游行，以标记所有“ Plus”，“ Pro”和“ Max”士兵的标签，Dell现在采用命名计划困扰着新的混乱水平。 PC Maker在CES 2025宣布，它的新笔记本电脑，台式机和监视器等XP，Inspiron，Latitude，Precision和Optiplex等剪切名称，并用三个主要产品线代替它们：Dell（是的，Just Dell ），Dell Pro Pro Pro Pro Pro Pro和Dell Pro Max。

这很简单，真的。您可以选择Dell Pro Premium，它不如Dell Pro Max Plus好，但两者都比Dell Premium好，而Dell Premium实际上根本不是Premium 。简单的。

当一家公司愿意无耻地复制苹果，但他们的机构营销官僚机构完全使它完全搞砸了，这并不有趣。如果戴尔愿意擦除其现有的品牌板岩，那么他们很容易地设计出一种形容词的分类法，该分类法创造了一个层次结构，该层次结构比Apple的层次更为明显，更直观（例如，“ Max”有时并不总是最大的）。

entry.summary: 不要因泡沫而分心。让我们看看会发生什么。
entry.content:
马克·扎克伯格（Mark Zuckerberg）今天宣布了Meta将在Facebook，Instagram和（我认为）线程中应用内容审核的方式进行重大变化。他的主要公告是一个视频， 这里有一个非正式的成绩单。扎克伯格本人在线程上总结了自己的观点，我将在下面注释：

1/用社区笔记替换事实检查器，从美国开始。

这听起来...好吗？ Twitter/X的几乎所有内容都在Musk下更糟的是，但是社区笔记似乎是一个实际上效果很好的模型。到目前为止，我最喜欢的两个社交平台是蓝调和Mastodon。两者都不是事实检查者。而且我从未见过任何证据表明梅塔的事实检查者曾经检查过一个事实。 （也许这就是团队在Lumon的Macrodata改进中所做的？）

2/简化我们的内容政策，并消除对移民和性别等主题的限制，这些主题与主流话语脱节。

这似乎也很好。让人们吐出他们想喷射的东西。这个问题从来都不是关于是否应该允许用户表达关于主题Z的意见。问题一直是关于哪些意见算法平台选择推广的意见。我可以专门针对Twitter/x进行构架。根据埃隆·马斯克（Elon Musk）的所有权，您几乎可以表达任何想要的政治观点。那太棒了。但是，根据我在马斯克时代的经验，我不确定有人会不同意这一点 - 倾向于提高算法的政治观点是那些与马斯克/特朗普议程保持一致的观点。

我不想做一个假设的例子。我刚刚去了X.com，并寻找“希拉里·克林顿自由勋章”。以相反的顺序，我的搜索结果中的第三条推文（屏幕快照）是克林顿基金会帐户的祝贺推文。第二个是希拉里·克林顿（Hillary Clinton）自己的帐户的一条推文，感谢拜登总统（Biden）总统，并伴随着拜登（Biden）的照片，贝登（Biden）固定在白宫脖子上的奖牌。但是我的结果中的第一条推文来自“博士。 Clown，PhD” ，展示了Clinton转变为燃烧的角恶魔的AI生成的视频。

我合法认为，允许尊敬的小丑博士可以向X发布这样的视频。不需要对其进行事实检查。 （尽管有人应该让塔克·卡尔森（Tucker Carlson）知道这不是真实的。）当然，不应该被禁止。但是我也有零兴趣在一个平台上寻找政治新闻，该平台在寻找“希拉里·克林顿自由勋章”时会促进这种非鹅AI生成的斜坡高于希拉里·克林顿（Hillary Clinton）自己的有关该奖项的推文。 1

问题不是元元素现在允许的帖子，而是，他们的算法将促进什么样的帖子，以及向谁推广。我并不是想在这里成为一个波利安娜 - 我完全知道那种认为Twitter/X在Elon Musk的所有权下有所改善而不是拒绝的人，他们不仅认为他们的帖子应该是允许，但应该将它们晋升为广泛的观众，而算法促销的任何范围都不是邪恶的“影子爆炸”的结果。如果Meta打算开始向我展示尊敬的Clown博士之类的内容，那么我就出去了。如果他们只是想向那些认为这很聪明的人展示更多的希拉里 - 克林顿 - iis-a-a-demon ai slop，那很好。

因此，让我们看看Meta在这里的含义。我希望以一种奇怪的方式希望这意味着Meta的平台变得完全有毒纳粹。我很想像现在对X一样对另一个社交媒体平台的关注。

3/改变我们如何执行政策来消除绝大多数审查制度错误，通过将过滤器重点放在解决非法和高度违反违规的情况下，并要求更高的信心使我们的过滤器采取行动。

META通过引用他们已审查的内容的具体示例来说明这一政策更改，但不再会。没有具体的示例，这是毫无意义的，并且可能导致从元平台发生巨大变化到根本不变的任何内容。承认您犯了错误，而没有考虑到这些错误并没有真正承认除了震动的变化以外的任何事情。 （这在很大程度上适用于扎克伯格今天的整个公告。）

在Meta Company博客上的随附帖子中（奇怪的是，在agip.fb.com域中托管），新促成的首席全球事务官乔尔·卡普兰（Joel Kaplan W.布什的两个术语 -写道：

随着时间的流逝，我们开发了复杂的系统来管理我们的平台上的内容，这对我们来说越来越复杂。结果，我们一直在过度遵守规定，限制了合法的政治辩论，并审查了太多的琐碎内容，并使太多的人遭受了挫败的执法行动。

例如，在2024年12月，我们每天删除了数百万个内容。尽管这些动作不到每天生产的内容的不到1％，但我们认为其中十分之一的动作可能是错误（即，内容可能实际上并未违反我们的政策）。

有数百万个例子，据说是20％的假阳性率，他们应该引用很多例子。但是卡普兰不是一个。可能是空的姿势。促进直接右翼观点可能是一种偏离。只有他们的实际行动才能揭示答案。

回到扎克伯格：

4/带回公民内容。我们正在收到人们希望再次看到此内容的反馈，因此我们将其恢复到Facebook，Instagram和线程，同时努力使社区友好和积极。

从表面上看，这似乎是大致翻译成“近年来我们已经轻描淡写了政治内容，最明显的是2024年，选举年，现在选举结束了，特朗普重新上任，当然，让我们带来政治内容返回。对我来说，这似乎是错误的时机，但是无论如何。我看不到这个时机，因为扎克伯格将他的拇指放在了特朗普方面。梅塔（Meta）一直在取消优先考虑所有政治内容，如果他们现在真的要重新确定它，那将与他的支持者一样适用于特朗普的批评者。

考虑一下时机是否被逆转，梅塔的平台在整个2024年都是政治上的全部自由，政治上的晋升到了每个人的饲料的顶端，今天，特朗普再次上任之前的两周，扎克伯格宣布元宣布元通过强调其所有平台上的“公民内容”，以减少众所周知的厨房中的热量。那些决心认为他做出的任何决定是特朗普的袋子（可能是正确的，也可能是不正确的），今天将在今天上下跳跃，认为扎克伯格无耻地试图使特朗普的批评者在第二次就职典礼的浪潮中沉默。

在我看来，显而易见的是，近年来，梅塔（Meta）决定即使以参与为代价，也决定避开有争议的内容。他们认为他们如何重新提高政治（或在扎克的委婉语音，公民）内容的同时，“保持社区友好和积极”，我看不到。只要特朗普仍然是民族人物，他甚至还没有重新任职，就没有任何“友好和积极”在我们的政治话语中。整个过程主要亮点是，扎克伯格没有指导原则 - 零，齐尔奇，nada - 在梅塔本身以外的任何“成功”以外的任何其他平台之后。是关于您和您最亲密的朋友和家人的吗？还是跟随名人影响者？政治是的，还是政治不是吗？几年前的答案都是不同的，几年后它们可能会再次不同。

5/将我们的信任，安全和内容审核从加利福尼亚州移出，并将我们的美国内容审查转移到德克萨斯州。这将有助于消除偏见员工过于审查内容的担忧。

首先，加利福尼亚和德克萨斯州的政治对立面是平衡的，但德克萨斯州的红色略低于加利福尼亚是蓝色的。考虑最近的选举。

加利福尼亚：

  • 卡马拉·哈里斯（Kamala Harris）：9,276,179票（59％）
  • 唐纳德·特朗普：6,081,697票（38％）

德克萨斯州：

  • 唐纳德·特朗普：6,393,597票（56％）
  • 卡马拉·哈里斯（Kamala Harris）：4,835,250票（42％）

不过，德克萨斯州是一个很大的州。如果Meta将其内容审核团队移至Austin，那么他们将搬到一个投票支持Kamala Harris 69-29的县，比整个加利福尼亚州更“蓝色”。

但这都是表演性的。扎克伯格的地理解释只要元本身总部位于加利福尼亚州的门洛公园，就没有意义。我们是否相信Meta内容节制中的任何偏见都是由主持人本身决定的 - 在很大程度上甚至不是全部是为第三方公司工作的承包商？ 2019年， 凯西·牛顿（Casey Newton）在《边缘》（The Verge）撰写了一篇壮观的文章，其中几位“ 800”左右的员工在佛罗里达州坦帕（Tampa）的一个网站上为供应商的Facebook内容主持人工作。 （佛罗里达州的2024年选举结果几乎与德克萨斯州的选举结果相同，特朗普为56-43。）

正是算法推动了对元平台的讨论，而引导它们在加利福尼亚工作的工程师。但实际上，无论公司的全体员工在怀俄明州还是佛蒙特州工作都无关紧要。最终，Meta的每个人都回答了Zuckerberg。

6/与特朗普总统合作，推动反对外国政府，追随美国公司以审查更多。美国对世界上自由表达的宪法保护措施最为​​强大，并且在美国政府的支持下，抵制政府过度审查趋势的最佳方法是。

马克·古巴（Mark Cuban）关于如何起作用的理论，在对扎克伯格（Zuckerberg）线程的答复中：

翻译：美国人将看到您认为审查元服务的国家对产品的关税，以此迫使他们消除影响您在这些国家盈利能力的任何限制。

另外：您将有刻薄的帖子来拿起不再有限制的帖子，使其更加明确，并训练您的AI模型

另外：Bluesky现在是唯一具有允许用户控制自己体验的工具的调节社交媒体平台

对我来说，这似乎就像扎克伯格穿着杂志帽，说：“他妈的，是的，特朗普！”取悦老板。我看不到特朗普政府会根据美国社交媒体公司的欧盟内容审核和数据隐私政策来改变欧盟的关税计划。而且，我当然看不到欧盟根据对无关物理商品的王牌征收关税改变其内容和隐私法规。但谁知道呢？没有人。试图预测特朗普实际可能会做什么，就像试图预测一张公平牌的牌一样。

最终，扎克伯格和梅塔似乎与特朗普保持一致。我对特朗普当选后的看法是，尽我所能停止关注他所说的一切。我只注意他的所作所为。与任何其他国家领导人一起，他们的话语与最终的行动之间存在相关性，这使他们注意他们所说的值得。有了特朗普，几乎没有相关性，而他无休止的令人毛骨悚然的宣言除了分心。

元也是如此。还记得他们的“监督委员会”吗？据说它仍然在那里。他们今天甚至以可悲的是“嘿，马克，还记得我们吗？我们还在这里。 ”声明。事实证明，这是一个完全的笑话，没有实际影响，更不用说对公司平台的授权。令人震惊。但是，许多新闻媒体的想法是，监督委员会在其哑剧存在的几年中以任何方式都是严肃的努力，线和坠子。

今天的元公告听起来很重要，但美国军方可能会侵入格陵兰岛要求其领土的观念也很重要。不要因泡沫而分心。让我们看看会发生什么。

entry.summary: I think it's correct for Apple to leave this in control of users, not developers. But Apple really does need to make it more clear what is an AI-generated summary and what is a verbatim original notification.
entry.content:
Liv McMahon and Natalie Sherman, reporting for BBC News :

The company, in its first acknowledgement of the concerns, on Monday said it was working on a software change to “further clarify” when the notifications are summaries that have been generated by the Apple Intelligence system. The tech giant is facing calls to pull the technology after its flawed performance.

The BBC complained last month after an AI-generated summary of its headline falsely told some readers that Luigi Mangione, the man accused of killing UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson, had shot himself.

On Friday, Apple's AI inaccurately summarised BBC app notifications to claim that Luke Littler had won the PDC World Darts Championship hours before it began — and that the Spanish tennis star Rafael Nadal had come out as gay.

This marks the first time Apple has formally responded to the concerns voiced by the BBC about the errors, which appear as if they are coming from within the organisation's app.

All of the following things are true:

  • All of Apple Intelligence is labelled “beta”.
  • People generally know what “beta” means.
  • Apple is promoting the hell out of Apple Intelligence to consumers, and its advertisements hide, rather than emphasize, its “beta” quality.
  • The promotion of a feature is an implicit encouragement to, you know, actually use it.
  • Apple Intelligence has to be opted into, and once enabled, can be turned off.
  • Apple Intelligence notification summaries are marked with an icon/glyph, sort of like the “↪︎” Unicode glyph with a few horizontal lines to suggest text encapsulated by the arrow — a clever icon to convey an abstract concept , to be sure.
  • The meaning of that icon/glyph is not at all obvious unless you know to look for it, and most users — even those who opted in to Apple Intelligence understanding that it was “beta” and might produce erroneous results — don't know to look for that particular glyph.

Thus, even to a user well aware of what they opted into, when they get a notification summary from “BBC News” that claims, say, that Luigi Mangione shot himself, it is perfectly reasonable for that user to presume it was BBC News reporting that Luigi Mangione shot himself.

Apple's statement to BBC News said:

“A software update in the coming weeks will further clarify when the text being displayed is summarization provided by Apple Intelligence. We encourage users to report a concern if they view an unexpected notification summary.”

No word from Apple on what this clarification will look like, but if it's clear enough, that sounds like a reasonable path forward. These notification summaries are very useful overall, in my experience. The mistake rate is very low and the utility is very high. But it really ought to be crystal clear what is an Apple-Intelligence-generated summary and what is not.

Calls for Apple to entirely remove the feature are hysterical nonsense. But what's conspicuously missing from Apple Intelligence is a way for individual app developers to opt out of it. For a developer to say, effectively, “Never offer summaries of this app's notifications.” That would alleviate some of this problem, but not all — because some news notifications come from apps that don't belong to the publisher whose headlines are being summarized, like an email app or a news aggregation app like Apple News.

But I can also see why Apple doesn't want to offer such an option to developers. To whom do notifications belong — the developer of the app that generates them, or the user who is receiving them? My oft-cited rule of thumb is that Apple's priorities are in a clear order:

  1. Apple itself.
  2. 用户。
  3. 开发商。

From that perspective, it's clear why Apple doesn't offer developers the option to opt out of having their notifications summarized by Apple Intelligence. First, Apple doesn't want them to opt out. Second, these notifications belong to the users receiving them, not the developers sending them. Thus, it's up to the users whether the feature is enabled at all, and to control which apps might be exempt from it (Settings → Notifications → Summarize Notifications). If you think about it, it's not much different from email. The sender of an email doesn't get to opt out of inbox filtering. If a developer does not want their notifications summarized by Apple Intelligence under any circumstances, then they should stop sending notifications.

I think it's correct for Apple to leave this in the control of users, not developers. But Apple really does need to make it more clear what is an AI-generated summary and what is a verbatim original notification. And, of course, it really needs to reduce the number of these errors. If a human editor had made this number of egregious mistakes in a single month, they'd have lost their job.

entry.content:

David Shipley, The Post's opinions editor, said in a statement that he respected Ms. Telnaes and all she had given to The Post “but must disagree with her interpretation of events.”

Look, this is bullshit. It is risible to suggest that the world's most powerful billionaires — men who control Facebook, Amazon, The Washington Post, The Los Angeles Times, Disney, ABC News, and OpenAI — aligning themselves with an aspiring autocrat is unworthy of two columns (one satirical) and a drawing.

  • “The 10 best things Biden did in 2024” by Marc Thiessen
  • “Dave Barry's 2024 year in review” by Dave Barry
  • “24 good things that happened in 2024” by the Editorial Board
  • “2025 promises to be tumultuous. Here's our New Year's resolution” by the Editorial Board
  • “How poker players keep New Year's resolutions” by Annie Duke

entry.title: The Intricacy of ASML's Extreme Ultraviolet Lithography Machines
entry.content:
Fascinating piece by Ben Cohen for The Wall Street Journal ( News+ link ):

And there are two things I learned about the EUV tool I saw that I can't get out of my head:

  1. ASML teamed up with a German optical company to develop mirrors so flat that if they were scaled up to the size of Germany itself, their largest imperfection would be less than a millimeter.

  2. The precision of EUV machines is comparable to directing a laser beam from your house and hitting a ping-pong ball on the moon.

It took decades for these absurdly sophisticated machines to make their way from labs to fabs. And until recently, it wasn't clear if the company's audacious bet on EUV lithography would ever pay off. In 2012, ASML was strapped for cash and sold a 23% equity stake to Intel, Samsung Electronics and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, which meant its biggest customers were literally invested in the company's success.

ASML soon ramped up production — very, very slowly. The company delivered the first EUV system in 2010. Not until 2020 did it deliver the 100th. And last year was a busy one: ASML shipped a total of 42 EUV machines.

The piece is also a profile of one ASML engineer, Brienna Hall, who is one of a small cadre of frontline support engineers who keep these machines operating perfectly. The article's headline, though, is bizarrely framed to suggest that she's the only such support engineer in the world. The weird headline distracts from an otherwise fascinating story.

entry.title: Simon Willisons's Approach to Running a Link Blog
entry.content:
Speaking of Simon Willison, I greatly enjoyed this post from last week, with some of the self-imposed principles he follows writing his excellent eponymous blog. Amongst them:

  • I always include the names of the people who created the content I am linking to, if I can figure that out. Credit is really important, and it's also useful for myself because I can later search for someone's name and find other interesting things they have created that I linked to in the past. If I've linked to someone's work three or more times I also try to notice and upgrade them to a dedicated tag . [...]
  • If the original author reads my post, I want them to feel good about it . I know from my own experience that often when you publish something online the silence can be deafening. Knowing that someone else read, appreciated, understood and then shared your work can be very pleasant.
  • A slightly self-involved concern I have is that I like to prove that I've read it . This is more for me than for anyone else: I don't like to recommend something if I've not read that thing myself, and sticking in a detail that shows I read past the first paragraph helps keep me honest about that.

Every step of the way, I found myself nodding my head, thinking to myself, I do that too! — right down to creating tags for people after I've mentioned their work or simply credited their bylines a few times. (The difference is that Willison seemingly isn't a procrastinator, and I am, so my decades of tagging aren't yet exposed to anyone but me.)

Then I got to this:

There are a lot of great link blogs out there, but the one that has influenced me the most in how I approach my own is John Gruber's Daring Fireball . I really like the way he mixes commentary, quotations and value-added relevant information.

And now it doesn't seem quite as amazing that I was nodding my head in agreement with each of his guidelines. But, call me biased, it's still a hell of a good start to a blogging rulebook.

entry.summary: OpenAI is to this decade's generative-AI revolution what Netscape was to the 1990s' internet revolution.
entry.content:
From an un-bylined post from OpenAI's board of directors on Friday:

The hundreds of billions of dollars that major companies are now investing into AI development show what it will really take for OpenAI to continue pursuing the mission. We once again need to raise more capital than we'd imagined. Investors want to back us but, at this scale of capital, need conventional equity and less structural bespokeness.

My take on OpenAI is that both of the following are true:

  • OpenAI currently offers, by far, the best product experience of any AI chatbot assistant.
  • There is no technical moat in this field, and so OpenAI is the epicenter of an investment bubble.

Thus, effectively, OpenAI is to this decade's generative-AI revolution what Netscape was to the 1990s' internet revolution. The revolution is real, but it's ultimately going to be a commodity technology layer, not the foundation of a defensible proprietary moat. In 1995, investors mistakenly thought investing in Netscape was a good way to bet on the future of the open internet and the World Wide Web in particular. Investing in OpenAI today is a bit like that — generative AI technology has a bright future and is transforming the world, but it's wishful thinking that the breakthrough client implementation is going to form the basis of a lasting industry titan.

There's even a loosely similar origin story. Netscape started life as Mosaic , a free-of-charge browser that debuted in January 1993 and instantly revolutionized the nascent-but-still-obscure World Wide Web by adding support for images. Mosaic was developed and released by a team led by Marc Andreessen at the National Center for Supercomputing Applications ( NCSA ). A year later Andreessen and his team left NCSA and, with Silicon Graphics founder James Clark, founded Netscape Communications Corporation, using the Mosaic browser as the foundation for Netscape Navigator. OpenAI's whole “ forget about this being a public-benefit thing, let's make it a for-profit thing ” transition is very reminiscent of the Mosaic-to-Netscape transition.

The biggest difference is that Netscape went public quickly , and that's when the investment money poured in. NCSA Mosaic debuted in January 1993 and Netscape's IPO was just 2.5 years later, in August 1995. OpenAI has raised tens of billions of dollars already — $13 billion from Microsoft alone — while still in this uncertain transition from an ostensibly not-for-profit foundation to a totally-for-profit company.

OpenAI's board now stating “We once again need to raise more capital than we'd imagined” less than three months after raising another $6.6 billion at a valuation of $157 billion sounds alarmingly like a Ponzi scheme — an argument akin to “ Trust us, we can maintain our lead, and all it will take is a never-ending stream of infinite investment. ”

entry.title: Coding Font Selection 'Tournament'
entry.content:
Via Jason Snell (back in October), who points first to this thread on Mastodon where a few of us posted about our preferences for the fonts we use for writing, and then describes this fun “tournament” from Typogram that lets you pick your favorite monospaced coding font from 32 choices. One limitation is that the only options are free fonts — some of my favorite monospaced fonts aren't free and thus aren't included (eg Consolas , Berkeley Mono , or Apple's SF Mono ). Another limitation is that some of the fonts in the tournament just plain suck. But it's really pretty fun.

It's also a good thing I procrastinated on linking to this for two months — it's improved greatly in the weeks since Snell linked to it. The example code is now JavaScript, not CSS, which is a much better baseline for choosing a programming font. And there are some better font choices now.

I highly recommend you disable showing the font names while you play, to avoid any bias toward fonts you already think you have an opinion about. But no matter how many times I play, I always get the same winner: Adobe's Source Code Pro . My second favorite in this tournament is IBM Plex Mono . The most conspicuous omission: Intel One Mono .

★

entry.summary: Bezos can still be a hero in this story. But his only move is to sell.
entry.content:
Mike Allen, in the bizarre notes-hurriedly-jotted-on-a-napkin house prose style of Axios :

Kara Swisher, the popular podcaster and pioneering tech journalist, is trying to round up a group of rich people to fund a bid for the Washington Post, she told us.

One big problem: Jeff Bezos, the owner, has shown no interest in selling.

Why it matters: Swisher — who started in the Post mailroom, and became an early tech reporter at the paper (and later one of the first at The Wall Street Journal) — believes the Amazon founder will eventually want to sell, since the paper has become a managerial nightmare.

Like many, Swisher thinks Bezos should sell since he has other financial and personal interests — like space tech — that are more important to him, and can conflict with his Post ownership.

“The Post can do better,” she told us. “It's so maddening to see what's happening. ... Why not me? Why not any of us?”

This would be an excellent outcome. Bezos should sell. These last few months should make clear to him that he should not own the Post . Swisher would be an excellent publisher. Her entire career has been focused on sharp, smart, good journalism.

One simple fact that's been clear to me ever since I worked (as a designer in the promotions department) at The Philadelphia Inquirer in the late 1990s is that news publications need to be owned by people who are devoted to the core pursuit of journalism. The Inquirer was a world-class newspaper at the time. I played supposedly casual lunchtime softball with colleagues from across the company on Fridays, and only after a few weeks found out that around half the regulars in our group had won Pulitzer prizes. When I learned this I was astonished. It gave me a moment's pause about hitting the ball as hard as I could. I didn't want to injure journalistic royalty. (But just a moment's pause. It was a friendly game but we were all competitive bastards.) There was a stretch in the late 1980s when the Inquirer, under the leadership of editor Gene Roberts , won more Pulitzers than The New York Times and Washington邮政。 That culture, and the journalists, remained in place through the 1990s. But The Inquirer was owned at the time by Knight Ridder, a national conglomerate, and Knight Ridder wasn't in the newspaper business for the journalism. They were in it for the profits. Which, at the time, were quite lucrative. There was one quarter where word spread that Knight Ridder brass was pissed because The Inquirer's profit margin for the quarter had dropped to 19 percent. 20 was the magic number. Newspapers were still minting money from the classified ads. Much of the great editorial and reporting talent at The Inquirer soon left for other publications, like The New York Times, The Washington Post, and Time magazine.它崩溃了。 Ownership matters.

There are many types of businesses a wealthy person can own as a mere hobby, in which the business can thrive under such ownership, simply by the owner allowing talented dedicated professionals to run the operation. A wealthy dilettante owner can help many such businesses, by providing the capital to hire great talent. Journalism is not one of those businesses. Profits are important because profits maintain independence and pay for talent. Investigative reporting is expensive. But independence is more important than anything, and there can be no true independence for a publication when the owner is not committed to the cause.

We see it with The Washington Post under Bezos, when he kiboshed the paper's endorsement of Kamala Harris so as not to antagonize Donald Trump. We see it with this shithead owner of the LA Times , Patrick Soon-Shiong, whose latest dictum is for the paper's editorial board to, I swear, “take a break” from writing about Donald Trump . Instructing a daily newspaper's editorial board to take a break from writing about the incoming president of the United States is like telling a bar to take a break from selling beer. It's the entire point of the establishment. 1

We see it most clearly, perhaps, with Disney's ownership of ABC News. Disney last week settled a bullshit defamation lawsuit with Trump, for $16 million, that they clearly should have taken to trial , choosing instead to embarrass and humiliate, rather than proudly stand behind, their own talent, George Stephanopoulos. As Josh Marshall eloquently argues , settling that defamation suit on those obsequious, cowardly terms made perfect sense for Disney. It wasn't worth the risk to Disney's brand and overall interests. But it was devastating to ABC News's brand and reputation. The simple truth is that Disney's core business isn't journalism.甚至还差得远。 It's not that ABC News's journalistic integrity doesn't matter to Disney. It's that it's just one small factor to Disney. Disney would fight tooth and nail to defend Mickey Mouse, but George Stephanopoulos's face isn't printed on t-shirts at Disneyland.

Say what you want (and there is much to be said) about the Ochs-Sulzberger family's dynastic ownership and control of The New York Times Company , but whatever their faults, there can be little argument that nothing is more important to them than the Times's core mission of independent journalism. If The New York Times had been faced with this same defamation lawsuit from Trump for the same reason (whether the word “rape” fairly describes the sexual assault he was found to have committed in E. Jean Carroll's victorious civil lawsuit against him , in which she was awarded $88 million), they would not have capitulated as Disney did. The New York Times did not hesitate to strongly endorse Kamala Harris .等等。

Even Rupert Murdoch exemplifies this. When News Corp cashed in and sold assets five years ago, Murdoch sold 21st Century Fox — the film and TV assets — and held onto the news assets. And the buyer was Disney , whose core business is aligned with those assets: entertainment. Murdoch's News Corp, aptly named to describe its primary purpose, still owns The Wall Street Journal, The New York Post, The Times and The Sun in the UK, and more . And the Murdoch family, of course, owns a controlling share of Fox Corporation , the parent of Fox News. Say what you want about Murdoch too (and I would say, with no hyperbole, that he's singlehandedly responsible for more of what's gone wrong in the United States over the last quarter century than any person alive, including Donald Trump, who I believe would never have even run for president, let alone become president twice, without the deeply pernicious and pervasive influence of Fox News), but he built and owns his news media empire because he believes in its core mission, as dastardly as his vision is for what journalism ought to be.

Good intentions aren't enough. Disney, all things considered, has never wanted ABC News to be anything other than a bastion of quality TV-style journalism. Bezos, heretofore, has been a fine steward at the Post. But it's easy to be a good owner of a good news outlet when times are normal. It's when times are hard, whether financially, or more crucially, when truth speaks to malicious power, that it becomes essential for the owner to be in the game first and foremost for the mission of journalism itself. Those are moments of contention and conflict and risk, and like a don's consigliere , a news publication in conflict with malicious power needs an owner with the stomach for war.

The Washington Post's own illustrious history speaks to this. In 1971, whistleblower Daniel Ellsberg leaked the Pentagon Papers , the Defense Department's internal secret history of the Vietnam War (which Ellsberg had helped write). Per The New York Historical :

The first article on the Pentagon Papers ran on the front page of the Times on June 13, 1971. Two days later, the Nixon administration sued, asking for an injunction to halt any further publication of the papers. US District Court Judge Murray Gurfein issued a temporary restraining order — the first in US history that restrained the press prior to publication. [...]

The court order was still in place on June 16, when the Washington Post's national editor, Ben Bagdikian, returned from Ellsberg's home in Boston carrying a partial copy of the Pentagon Papers. The Post's president and publisher Katharine Graham was faced with the decision: to publish or not? Defying the court order carried significant risk: the Washington Post Company had just gone public, and reporting on the Pentagon Papers meant risking a criminal charge that would imperil its $35 million stock offering and put the paper's financial future in jeopardy. A criminal conviction would also give the FCC an excuse to strip the Washington Post Company of the licenses to its lucrative television stations, WTOP in Washington, DC, and Florida's WJXT. Doing so would stand up for freedom of the press.

On June 17, reporters, editors, and lawyers gathered at executive editor Ben Bradlee's house to wrangle over the question of whether or not to publish. Meanwhile, Katharine Graham was hosting a farewell party for the paper's departing business manager in her stately Georgetown home. Interrupted in the middle of her laudatory speech, she was summoned to the phone and asked to make a decision that could, one way or the other, destroy her paper. Though her lawyers opposed publication, her reporters and editors argued that failing to publish would be “gutless” and erode the Post's credibility. Frightened and tense, as she later wrote in her Pulitzer Prize-winning memoir , Graham “took a big gulp and said, 'Go ahead, go ahead, go ahead.我们走吧。 Let's publish.”

In the face of possible prison time — not only for her staff but for herself — and the risk of financial ruin for the paper and her family, Graham said, “Let's go. Let's publish.” Jeff Bezos didn't even have the intestinal fortitude to allow the Post editorial board to publish an utterly unsurprising election endorsement. Katharine Graham, portrayed by Meryl Streep, was the hero of a great Steven Spielberg film, The Post . In a hypothetical sequel portraying the events that led to Trump's second term, Jeff Bezos would be portrayed by the actor who played the cowardly lawyer snatched on the can by the T. rex in Jurassic Park .

For those readers and viewers who enjoy and support Rupert Murdoch's publications and channels for what they are, he is the best owner imaginable. He stands behind their work and their mission. His media outlets are his life's work. ABC News doesn't hold an iota of that value to Disney. The same is true for what The Washington Post means to Jeff Bezos. It's obvious Bezos does care about the Post. But it's also now obvious that he does not care nearly enough.

The Washington Post would hold such value to an ownership consortium led by Kara Swisher. Bezos can still be a hero in this story. But his only move is to sell.

  1. Soon-Shiong is, in a very obvious yet perhaps easily overlooked way, a very different sort of bad newspaper owner than Bezos. Or than Disney is as owner of ABC News. Neither Bezos nor Disney supports Trump. They're not trying to turn their outlets into pro-Trump propaganda channels. They're not meddling in day-to-day editorial decisions. They just don't want to piss Trump off. They don't want to fellate him every day à la Fox News or The Wall Street Journal editorial page ; just one big public blow job here or there to avoid Trump's ire. That's bad enough. It's shameful, and a dereliction of duty. But Soon-Shiong is seemingly a true believer. He is pro-Trump. But he owns a real newspaper full of real journalists, not propagandists, with a liberal editorial and opinion section. It doesn't mix. It's like a flat-earther buying a space company like Blue Origin or SpaceX. His beliefs don't mix with the existing premise, purpose, and culture of the company he now owns. ↩︎
